title: Trump Administration Looks to Supreme Court to Rein In Consumer Finance Agency
text:
WASHINGTON—The Trump administration told the Supreme Court Tuesday that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is unconstitutional because Congress limited the president’s power to remove the agency’s director before his or her five-year term expires.

Two federal appeals courts have upheld the CFPB’s structure, which is intended to insulate the director from political interference by allowing dismissal only for “inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office.” They relied on a 1935 Supreme Court precedent, known as Humphrey’s Executor, which approved similar protections for members of the Federal Trade Commission, who like the CFPB director are presidential appointees confirmed by the Senate.

Created under the 2010 Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, the CFPB was given stronger enforcement powers over the financial industry that backers believed would help prevent another economic meltdown like the mortgage-lending crisis that began in 2007.

But Republicans and other critics argue that the CFPB’s design interferes with the president’s constitutional power over the executive branch, allowing the bureau’s director, who may have taken office under a prior administration, to pursue a policy agenda contrary to that of the current president.

Tuesday’s brief, filed by Solicitor General Noel Francisco, reverses the position the CFPB took before the lower courts, continuing the Trump administration’s effort to reduce the bureau’s power and roll back other provisions of the Dodd-Frank Act that the banking industry complains are too burdensome.

The case at issue involves Seila Law LLC, an Orange, Calif., firm offering debt-relief services, that the CFPB began investigating over possible violations of consumer-protection laws. The firm sought to quash the investigation by arguing that the CFPB was unconstitutional.

In urging the Supreme Court to take the firm’s appeal, Mr. Francisco cites a dissenting opinion by Justice Brett Kavanaugh, written in January 2018 when he sat on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

While the majority opinion, by Judge Cornelia Pillard, found the CFPB similar to the FTC and other agencies Congress has sought to shield from political interference, then-Judge Kavanaugh’s dissent argued there was a critical difference: the Dodd-Frank law vested control of the bureau to a single director rather than a multi-member commission like the one upheld in Humphrey’s Executor.

“Multi-member independent agencies do not concentrate all power in one unaccountable individual, but instead divide and disperse power across multiple commissioners or board members. The multi-member structure thereby reduces the risk of arbitrary decision-making and abuse of power, and helps protect individual liberty,” he wrote.

The Justice Department said the court need not eliminate the CFPB but rather strike Dodd-Frank provisions preventing the president from firing the director at will.

If the Supreme Court agrees to hear the case, it may appoint an outside lawyer to argue the position abandoned by the Justice Department—that the director’s independence is constitutional.

The CFPB was the brainchild of Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D., Mass.), who as a Harvard law professor argued that a consumer-focused enforcement agency could help prevent financial-industry excesses. Republican opposition dissuaded President Obama from naming Ms. Warren the agency’s first director, prompting her successful run against Republican Sen. Scott Brown in 2012.

Sen. Warren, now a leading contender for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, couldn't immediately be reached for comment.

description: Critics argue the CFPB’s design interferes with the president’s constitutional power over the executive branch.
